intro: Jatropha platyandra, commonly known as the broadleaf jatropha, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of Africa. It is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family, characterized by its milky sap and showy, often colorful inflorescences. The plant typically grows as an annual herb, reaching heights of up to 1 meter, with broad, alternate leaves that are often lobed or palmately divided. Its flowers are small and clustered in cyathia, which are cup-like structures typical of the genus Jatropha. The plant is known for its toxic properties, with all parts containing irritants and toxins that can cause skin and gastrointestinal reactions in humans and animals.
